Situation1: Include each other in social activities and outings when possible.
Expectation2: Wash and condition clients' hair before cutting or styling
Situation2: Heavy product buildup is causing tight tangles that will impede scissors.
Story: I glanced at the appointment book and saw my sister’s name. She’d texted me earlier, excited about the party we were both invited to tonight, and I’d promised we’d go together. As her brother, I always tried to make her feel included, especially since she sometimes felt left out of my friend group. But now, sitting in my salon chair, I saw the thick, sticky residue in her hair—she’d tried a new styling gel, and it was a mess. As her hairdresser, I knew I had to wash and condition her hair thoroughly before I could even think about cutting or styling it. But she was already running late, and I could see her anxiety building. She wanted to skip the wash, just a quick trim so we could leave on time. I felt the pressure mounting—if I insisted on doing my job right, she’d be upset, maybe feel like I was putting work before her. But if I rushed, I’d be compromising my professional standards. My hands hovered over the sink, heart pounding, torn between being the brother she needed and the hairdresser I was trained to be.
